questions.stem: A patient reports falling asleep within 3 minutes of lying down, experiencing vivid dreams during brief naps, and 'losing muscle control' when laughing. Polysomnography shows sleep-onset REM periods. Which neurotransmitter system abnormality is most implicated in this condition?
options: Excessive GABAergic activity in the reticular formation
Deficiency of orexin/hypocretin in the lateral hypothalamus
Dopamine dysregulation in the substantia nigra
Serotonin depletion in the raphe nuclei
questions.explanation: This presentation is classic narcolepsy Type 1 with cataplexy (muscle weakness with emotion) and sleep-onset REM periods. Research has established that narcolepsy Type 1 results from loss of orexin (hypocretin)-producing neurons in the lateral hypothalamus, likely due to autoimmune destruction. CSF orexin levels are typically very low or undetectable in these patients.

questions.stem: A sleep study for a patient with excessive daytime sleepiness shows an apnea-hypopnea index (AHI) of 22 events/hour. Which findings would indicate obstructive rather than central sleep apnea? (Select all that apply)
options: Continued respiratory effort during apneic events
Oxygen desaturation following events
Absence of airflow with absent respiratory effort
Loud snoring and gasping arousals
Upper airway collapse visualized on endoscopy
questions.explanation: Obstructive sleep apnea is characterized by continued respiratory effort against a collapsed airway (distinguishing it from central apnea where effort is absent), loud snoring from partial obstruction, and demonstrable upper airway collapse. Oxygen desaturation occurs in both types. Central sleep apnea shows absence of both airflow AND respiratory effort.

questions.stem: Match each sleep disorder with its most characteristic polysomnographic finding.
questions.explanation: Narcolepsy Type 1 shows sleep-onset REM periods (SOREMPs) on MSLT. REM sleep behavior disorder shows REM without atonia, allowing dream enactment. PLMD shows periodic limb movements during sleep on leg EMG. Central sleep apnea shows apneic events without respiratory effort (versus obstructive where effort continues).

questions.stem: For each sleep disorder, select ALL appropriate first-line treatments.
questions.explanation: CBT-I is first-line for chronic insomnia (superior long-term outcomes to medications). For narcolepsy with cataplexy, modafinil treats sleepiness and sodium oxybate (Xyrem) uniquely treats both sleepiness and cataplexy. CPAP is first-line for moderate-severe OSA. BzRA agonists are second-line for insomnia due to dependency risks.

questions.stem: A patient reports difficulty initiating sleep, taking 90 minutes to fall asleep most nights for the past 4 months. They have developed anxiety about bedtime and spend extended time in bed trying to sleep. Sleep diary shows sleep efficiency of 62%. According to CBT-I protocols, the intervention targeting their extended time in bed is [[1]], while the intervention for their anxiety about sleep is [[2]]. The recommended sleep efficiency threshold before extending time in bed is [[3]].
questions.explanation: Sleep restriction limits time in bed to match actual sleep time, increasing sleep pressure and efficiency. Cognitive restructuring addresses dysfunctional beliefs and anxiety about sleep. In CBT-I protocols, time in bed is increased by 15-minute increments when sleep efficiency reaches 85% or higher.

questions.stem: A 45-year-old man presents with excessive daytime sleepiness, loud snoring, witnessed apneic episodes, and morning headaches. His BMI is 34 and neck circumference is 18 inches. Epworth Sleepiness Scale score is 16.

options: Obesity (BMI >30)
Male gender
Large neck circumference (>17 inches)
Witnessed apneas by bed partner
Diagnostic polysomnography
Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP)
Weight loss counseling
Immediate prescription of modafinil

questions.explanation: This presentation strongly suggests obstructive sleep apnea. All listed factors are established risk factors for OSA. Polysomnography is needed for diagnosis and severity assessment. CPAP is first-line treatment for moderate-severe OSA, and weight loss is an important adjunct. Modafinil would be premature before PSG confirmation and CPAP trial.

questions.stem: A patient has chronic insomnia and is starting CBT-I. Arrange these sleep restriction therapy steps in the correct order.
options: Calculate average total sleep time from 2-week sleep diary
Set initial prescribed time in bed equal to average sleep time (minimum 5 hours)
Maintain consistent wake time regardless of sleep quality
When sleep efficiency reaches 85%, increase time in bed by 15 minutes
Continue adjustments until optimal sleep duration achieved
questions.explanation: Sleep restriction begins with calculating baseline sleep from diary data, then prescribing time in bed matching actual sleep (â‰¥5 hours minimum for safety). Consistent wake time is maintained to consolidate sleep. Time in bed increases only when efficiency reaches 85%, continuing until optimal personal sleep need is established.

questions.stem: Categorize each sleep phenomenon according to whether it is a normal sleep finding or a pathological finding requiring clinical attention.
items: Sleep onset REM period on MSLT
REM sleep without atonia on PSG

Pathological Finding: Sleep onset REM period on MSLT
REM sleep without atonia on PSG

questions.explanation: Normal: sleep latency 15-20 minutes, PLMI <5/hour is normal, sleep efficiency >85% is healthy. Pathological: SOREMPs suggest narcolepsy, REM without atonia indicates REM sleep behavior disorder risk, AHI 15-30 indicates moderate sleep apnea requiring treatment.
